text:
Before HBS, I spent
eight years active duty

in the United
States Marine Corps,

where I was a Communications
Strategy and Operations Officer.

Both my husband and I
were in the Marine Corps.

We commissioned from the
United States Naval Academy.

So essentially I've been
in the military environment
for 12 years prior to HBS.

A week after I submitted
my round two application

to Harvard Business School,
I found out I was pregnant.

My husband and I had a really
long conversation about whether

or not I was going
to defer a year.

I decided that I was going
to go for it because one,

I can do hard things,
and two, I wanted

to be able to show my daughter
that we as women are strong,

we're powerful, and we
can do hard things, too.
HBS has been amazing.

I had an amazing internship
at a med device company

and I was fortunate enough to
get a return offer from them.

I had never negotiated an
offer before just because being

in the military, you're
just given a rank

and you're given a salary and
there's nothing to negotiate.
It kind of is what it is.

I went to CPD to negotiate
the terms a little bit.

They just gave me
the confidence to be
able to advocate for myself.

Having never really
negotiated a salary before,
it can be uncomfortable waters.

But the CPD coach gave me the
stats of other HBS students

who accepted the job
in this industry,

and we came to something
I'm very happy with.

And I think it's a
really good offer.

I found my internship and
ultimately my job offer through
12twenty.

The criteria, the way
you can filter things out

was very helpful for me because
I had very specific criteria

of what I was looking for as far
as an internship is concerned.

You're not alone
in this process.

You don't have to figure
everything out by yourself.

There are so many
resources, so many people

willing to help you:
sectionmates, CPD,
administration, teachers.

It's just so many
people willing to extend
an offer of help and guidance.

So I would say to any moms
out there or any moms-to-be,

if you are even
slightly thinking

about applying to
business school,

but the fact that you're
a mom is holding you back,

don't let it, because
the business world needs

people like you to apply and
to be leaders in the business
because we're awesome.
